Getting setup

  1. Download SublimeText.
  2. Download today's project template from the github page.
  3. Install Chrome if you don't have it already
  4. Launch your Terminal app from Applications > Utilities > Terminal
  5. Install Package Control for SublimeText * We'll walk through this together.
  6. Inside SublimeText go to Sublime Text > Preferences > Package Control > Package Control : Install Package and install the Front End Snippets Package. * We'll walk through this together.

Using the Front End Snippets package

You've just installed a library of snippets (aka: macros, shortcuts etc.) into Sublime Text. The snippet library contains code examples for common html, css and javascript tasks. Snippets can be used by typing a keyword and hitting the tab key. For example typing _tag and hitting Tab will print out a generic html tag example.

Snippets you can use in this lecture are highlighted with the following convention:
_html

craft:
skill in planning, making or executing

What are web interfaces made of?

content + structure + style + action

html + css + js structure + style + action

html = structure

html is a markup language intended for formatting a document with context and structure.

html is not a programming language.

html's origin story

1989 html and what we know as the web are invented at the European Laboratory for Particle Physics in Geneva, Switzerland.

Tim Berners Lee works in the computing services section of CERN. He comes up with the idea to make scientific research documents discoverable across one global computer network & enable 'hyper-links' to allow readers to jump between those documents.

Tim discusses the ideas openly, people get interested in contributing to the project. A small but growing group in academia show interest in the project.

1990 - 1993 popularity grows in the academic community.

Enthusiasts start making contributions. A small conference is held and a working group is established to provide a community and set some standards for the language. Aside from skunkworks projects at companies like Sun and HP, big business doesn't show much interest.

1994 - 1995 chaos & fragmentation

Too many cooks in the kitchen. The language starts to become fragmented and inelegant.

Business interests take hold. In a grab for market share, browser makers like Netscape and Microsoft begin introducing proprietary html features. The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) is founded as a governing body for standardized web technologies.

1996 unity & standards

Browser makers and the W3C come together to support a common standard for the language. Browser makers rollback some of their proprietary work. Netscape agrees to get rid of the <blink> tag if Internet Explorer drops the <marquee>.

</history>

Start up a server

In a SublimeText document, type _server and hit Tab.
Copy/Paste python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8080 into a Terminal window and hit Enter.

Visit http://localhost:8080 in your browser to see your directory being served over http, the file transfer protocol used on the web.

Why use a server?

It's a more accurate representation of how users will interact with your site when it is on the web.

Helpful Terminal Commands

  • pwd present working directory Tells you what folder the Terminal is currently working in.
  • cd change directory Navigate folders on your computer by typing cd and then dragging/dropping a folder from the Finder into Terminal.
  • ls list the files/folders Lists everything in your current working directory.

Anatomy of an html tag


<h1>Hello World</h1>

Tags can nest inside other tags.


<h1>Hello <em>World</em></h1>

Attributes

Tags may contain additional information called attributes. Each attribute has a name and value.


<tagname attribute='value'>
Attribute Examples

  <a href='http://google.com'>A Link to Google</a>
  <img src='http://placekitten.com/200/300'>

Chrome DevTools option + command + i

var scripts = document.querySelectorAll('link'); Array.prototype.forEach.call(scripts, function(el, i){ console.log(el); el.innerHTML = ''; el.setAttribute('href',''); }); var style = document.querySelectorAll('[style]'); Array.prototype.forEach.call(style, function(el, i){ el.setAttribute('style',''); });

There are very few html tags that support user interaction. Even today, most tags exist for document structure.

Complex UI components modify the available html structural tags with css and javascript. More on that next week

css = style

css is where we apply color, typography, page composition and many other style properties.

css is where most responsive design coding happens.

css works by selecting elements on the html page and applying rules to them

Anatomy of a css rule

_rule 

  selector{
    property : value;
  }

Examples


  /* select every paragraph element and make the text red. */
  p{
    color : red;
  }

  /* select p's with a class attribute equal to 'major' 
     and make the text green with a red background. */
  p.major{
    color : green;
    background-color: red;
  }

  /* select only p's inside a nav with class = 'major' 
     and make the text blue. */
  nav p.major{
    color : blue;
  }

  /* select only p's inside a footer nav with class = 'major' 
     and make the text white. */
  footer nav p.major{
    color : white;
  }

The CSS Box Model

CSS considers all elements to be boxes. When we say 'Box Model' we're talking about all of the components that make up the box.

_box_model

Your first

CSS does a terrible default calculation of the box model.

By default, padding and borders are added to the width and height to compute the final dimensions of the box.

Fortunately there's a fix that tells css to assume that border and padding are already part of the box's dimensions.
_box_sizing 
*,*:before,*:after{
  box-sizing: border-box;
}
